abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Simulated family data were analyzed using one‐ and two‐locus disease models to detect linkage. Regions of interest, found on chromosomes 3 and 5, were then further analyzed to look for evidence of locus interaction and/or genetic heterogeneity. Methods described by Falk [1993] were used to separate families into subsets likely to be genetically homogeneous. Based on the results, it was concluded that there were at least two distinct disease loci, one on chromosome 3 and one on chromosome 5, and that these loci were probably not interacting but were expressing two distinct forms of the disease. The identification of these loci was in agreement with the generating model. However, the analysis did not show any indication of a two‐locus form of the disease or detect a disease locus on chromosome 1. This could be due to lack of power and/or too small a sample size for the method of analysis.</jats:p>

reference.article-title: Effective strategies for linkage analysis of genetically heterogeneous traits
reference.author: Falk C

reference.article-title: Parametric and nonparametric linkage analysis: a unified multipoint approach
reference.author: Kruglyak L

reference.article-title: Analysis of complex diseases under oligogenic models and intrafamilial heterogeneity by the LINKAGE programs
reference.author: Lathrop GM

reference.article-title: Multilocus linkage analysis in humans: detection of linkage and estimation of recombination
reference.author: Lathrop GM

reference.article-title: Two‐trait‐locus linkage analysis: a powerful strategy for mapping complex genetic traits
reference.author: Schork NJ

title: Systematic search for disease loci for complex genetic traits: A study based on simulated population data
